DIV1.P: THE MISFORTUNES OF ANGER. A DRAMA, IN TWO PARTS.

Q.L: "We wonder at the Mischief we have done."

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, a Parlour.
DIV2.STAGE: Mary enters, lifts up a tambour frame which appears to have been thrown down, picks up the span∣gles, silks, &c,—She speaks.
DIV2.P:
SO Miss Juliet has been here, I see!—What put her into a rage with her tambour, I wonder?—Oh! I see, this rose-bud does not look well, so down it went, I'll warrant it, and here lie the span∣gles and twist thrown all over the floor. For my part, I wonder the
frame was not all broke to smash, it would have been like her.—Ah! here comes Miss Paulina! There's a young lady, marry, I wish our's was like her, but no hope of that!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Mary have you seen my cousin?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: No, Miss, not since breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I left her here at her tambour frame—She said she would work while I read to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Aye, Miss, but some∣thing has gone wrong since that.—Here I found the frame, and there lay the silks—Truly, I'm glad I was not here, they'd have been thrown at my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Perhaps she is gone to her own room, I'll seek her; if she comes there in the mean time, Mary tell her I am up stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes, Miss, to be sure I will.— (Paulina goes out.)—Ah! by my truth, there's some pleasure in doing any thing for you, one does not get pinched and called names!—So here's the Governess, yawning as usual, but just up.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Selwyn. (She speaks in a slow, dull manner, and yawns often.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Well, Mary!—Where's Miss Juliet?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I don't know, Ma'am, not I, she is in one of her passions to-day; every thing goes wrong with her; she was ready to fight with the looking-glass, while I dressed her this morning, and I don't know how many pinches I got for not being quick enough to please her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P:
She's a strange
girl, I can't help laughing at her sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary. (laughing.)
SP.P: 'Tis no laugh∣ing matter, ma'am, I can tell you that, and it only makes her worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: She fatigues me so! I really cannot stay with her long at a time,

SP.SPEAKER: Mary, (aside.)
SP.P: No, truly, you take care not to have too much trouble!

P.HI: Mrs. Selwyn draws a chair indo∣lently, and takes out her work

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Well, Mary, go and tell her to come to me, I want her to read.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Lord, ma'am I'm quite afraid to go, she won't mind me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn, (yawning.)
SP.P: And she'll fatigue me sadly too, well, never mind, she'll come bye∣and bye.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: What's the matter with you, Fanny, what are you crying for?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Miss Juliet!—Miss Juliet!—Oh dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Child, don't make so much noise, what has Miss Juliet done to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Why, ma'am, an please you she met me in the garden, a∣bout half an hour agone, I was a coming up, ma'am, to beg a little milk for my little sister, for mo∣ther is very bad, and so she said as how—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Don't talk so fast, let's hear what Miss Juliet did.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, and so ma'am, if you please, I met Miss Juliet; and so she asked me what I wanted, and so I told, and so the

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Grant me pa∣tience! How many more so's?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Don't make such a long story, Fanny, tell us, at once, what made you cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, I'm a going, so miss asked me to play wi' she, for she said his honour was gone out and Madam Selwyn wa'nt up, and Master Charles was gone to school, and Miss Paulina was up stairs, and she did not know what to do wi' herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: So, there's all the family disposed of.—Well, child, what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Then we went up stairs ma'am, and miss shewed me her doll, and we played, but at last,—Oh dear, oh dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: I never heard such a girl in my life.—What happened then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Why, miss beat me, yes, she did, ever so hard, and scratch'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: What, all at once, without any cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, cause I let the doll fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn,
SP.P: What nonsense!—Go away, child, take your milk, and bid the cook give you some broth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, thank you ma'am (Aside.)—But I wo'nt come here any more to be beat a∣bout so. (Mary and Fanny go out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Where's Fanny Wood?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Gone home, miss, do you think any body will stay where you are, to be beat and scratched?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
I don't care What
business had she to throw down my doll?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Do you think she did it on purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I don't know.—Let her take more care then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Has she spoil'd it?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Well then, what was there to be in such a rage a∣bout?—Come and read.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Not till I have dressed my doll.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Well,—make haste then— (A pause, Mrs. Selwyn works but slowly and idly, Juliet dresses her doll, at last, she stamps her foot, and says:—
You tiresome creature, won't you be dress'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: My stars, Miss Juliet, how you make one start—What is the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Why, my nasty doll is such a torment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Very pretty, to quarrel with a bit of painted wood!—Oh! you silly child!—Come, leave your doll, and let me hear you read.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I tell you I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Oh! you are a sweet little girl, so mild and so ob∣liging; how every body loves you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet, (Crying.)
SP.P: Let me alone then!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Pretty creature!—What a sweet face!—Look how your doll stares at you!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: (Rising in a passion, and throwing her doll across the room.)
I wish the doll was a thousand miles off, a little provoking crea∣ture!— (Mrs. Selwyn laughs.)—I won't be laugh'd at that I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P:
How will you
help it?—Leave off crying direct∣ly, or I will shut you up for two hours.— (Another pause, Juliet still cries, but by degrees becomes quiet, af∣ter some time she calls.)—Mary!—Mary

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: What now, mise?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I want Mary.— (calls)—Mary, I say!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Mercy, miss I came as soon as ever I heard you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: You are always so slow.—Take down my gold finch, and fetch me some feed and water.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes miss. (She reaches the bird down, then goes out, and returns with some water and seed.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Come my pretty, let your mistress feed you, I love you very much— (She feeds it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Yes, you love it vastly just now, but sometimes you are ready to wring its neck, when it does not eat to please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary. (aside.)
SP.P: One would think Mrs. Selwyn liked to see her in a passion, she delights so in teaz∣ing her!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.(feeding the bird)
SP.P: Oh, you little torment you won't eat out of my hand!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: There, I told you so, now, miss, you has better beat the bird, or throw it across the room, as you did your doll.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: So I will, if I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Do, I would ad∣vise you!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Dear ma'am, how can you?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
Come, eat then—You won't!—You nasty, little obsti∣nate, ungrateful creature,—I'll
teach you to teaze me, I will.— (She snatches the bird out of the cage in a passion, gives it a squeeze, then looks at it, and bursts into tears.)—Oh! Heaven, I have killed my bird!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh, dear, miss, I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Look at it, Mary, pray try if you can fetch it to life!—Oh my poor bird—Is it dead, Mary?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes, miss, you have killed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: It—I have killed it!—I that loved it so!—Oh! how un∣happy I am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Don't cry so, miss, you was not so much to blame now.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Dear Juliet, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh! cousin, why did you leave me?—I am never so naughty when you are with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: My dear, I have been seeking you, at last I heard you was playing with Fanny Wood, so then I sat down to write to mama—But what has happened?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Oh Miss Juliet has been in one of her usual furies.—I must dress.—I am tired out with her.—Mary will tell you, Miss Paulina. (She goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mary, (muttering.)
SP.P: And 'tis as much your fault as her's this time, I must say, teaze, teaze, for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Mary, what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Shall I tell, miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh! my cousin will hate me.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I hate you, my dear, no I shall pity you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Why, miss, my young lady was feeding her bird, and hurt it somehow, and 'tis dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: No, Paulina, that is not all; I was angry with my poor bird, I gave it a sudden squeeze, and killed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: My dear cousin, you almost redeem your faults by this openness of heart.—How I pity you, how much you must feel on this occasion!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: (weeping, but with gen∣tleness.) But you, who are so good, how much you must detest me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: To tell you the truth, Miss Paulina, my young lady was not so much to blame as she is sometimes, Mrs. Selwyn did teaze her sadly, that she did, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
But that was not my
bird's fault!—Ah, my poor bird, he will never eat out of my hand again!—How could I be so cruel as to hurt a little creature who loved me so dearly.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Leave us, Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Do not distress your∣self so much, my dear Juliet.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Do I not deserve to be distressed?

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: You have certainly been wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah! You do not know half how naughty I have been: I pinched Mary, I beat Fanny Wood!—What is it makes me so wicked, Paulina? I always know when I am so, and I am unhappy, then I fret, and do wrong again.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
I can easily conceive
all that, you are greatly to be piti∣ed.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: But you are the only person (except my father) who e∣ver speaks to me as if I had com∣mon sense!—Mary shrugs up her shoulders and leaves me as soon as she can.—Mrs. Selwyn laughs at me and treats me like a baby. It was but just now she bade me "look how my doll stared at me!" And that put me into such a pas∣sion, that I threw my doll across the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
Certainly Mrs. Sel∣wyn does not treat you properly, but that does not justify you. You are now, my dear, more than twelve years old; at that age, though children, we are no longer babies, but you do not seek to improve yourself. You read, indeed, be∣cause you love reading, but not
with a steady view to your own improvement, and almost all the remainder of your time is spent in dressing your doll and playing with Fanny Wood, who is too ignorant to be a proper companion for you; thus you tempt others to treat you like a baby.—I do not offend you?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: No, no,—I like to hear you because you speak to me gently, and I feel what you say. Pray, dear Paulina, tell me what I must do to be like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
My dear Juliet, I wish you a better example;—if you were with us, mama would soon teach you to be all your friends could wish.—But Juliet, with the understanding nature has given you, you may do much for yourself. In the words of a very great author I will tell you that
—"There is no soul
More able to direct you than yourself.
If with the sap of Reason you would quench
Or but allay the Fire of Passion!"—

Read more, and reflect—When∣ever you find yourself getting an∣gry leave the cause of your dis∣pleasure, take a book which amu∣ses you, and read till you find your∣self calm and easy. Struggle with your violent passions, and think to what dreadful consequences they will lead if you indulge them.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Consequences!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
Yes, my dear cousin, I know not to what an excess they may transport you in time, if they are not now opposed.—My mother told me, the other day, she had just read the history of a man, who, when a boy, squeezed his squirrel to death
as you did your bird, and when he grew up, after various crimes, be∣ing angry with his wife, his child, who was in her arms, happened to cry while he was speaking and, in a fit of passion, he laid his hand on it, and strangled it in a moment!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh! Heaven, how shocking; do you think it possible, Paulina, do you think it possible I should ever do so?

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
It is impossible to say to what extravagance passion may lead!—But yesterday you would have detested the idea of injuring your bird—and are we not told in the Bible, that when the Prophet foretold to Hazael Sec 8th Chapter of the Book of Kings. the miseries he would bring on his country, and the cruelties of which he would be
guilty he exclaimed, "Is thy ser∣vant a dog that he should do this great thing?"—And yet when he gave way to his passions, he exactly ver the Prophet's words.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh, Paulina! you te∣rify me extremely—I will indeed try to do good—I will not beat Fanny nor pinch Charles any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I wish you may not—It is time for us to dress, your father will be at home presently, and I hear Charles is just come from school. (They go out.)

DIV2.HEAD: THE Misfortunes of Anger. PART II.
DIV2.STAGE: Juliet enters from the garden, she draws a chair, sits down, and leads her head on her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
I HAVE a sad head-ach, it always comes when I cry so much.—How true is what Paulina said just now, that I make myself wretched by indulging my passions I—Why did nobody ever tell me so before?— (She takes a picture from her bosom and kisses it.—Oh, my dear mother!—You died too early to form by your example, the
daughter you loved so tenderly!—Wretched girl!—Why do I ever, for a moment, forget the character which my father drew of my mother when he gave me this picture,—"Be like your mo∣ther, my Juliet; she was mild and gentle to all, she was beloved by every one who knew her! her dy∣ing wish was, that you might be virtuous!—My child, be worthy of your mother!—Yes, those were exactly his words. Ah! how little do I fulfil her wishes!—I, who ill-treat the servant to whose care she intrusted my infancy—Who a∣buse a poor child whose situation should make me pity her!—I whom every body hates!—Torn by contrary feelings!—Capable of knowing when I do wrong, yet yielding to the next temptation.—In spite of my faults, am I not to be pitied?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Miss, my master bade me tell you he is going to Mr. Richley's, and shall be back in less than an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: What is the matter miss, you are crying?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I have reason to cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I am sure, miss, I don't know any young lady who might be happier.—You have the best of fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah! that is true.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: And here you have a fine house, where you are, as one may say, mistress, and a carriage, and every earthly thing you can wish.—Only think of the poor children down in the village: the little Wood's whose mother is so sick, and who are half starved!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Alas, yes!—And I have ill-treated poor Fanny!—My dear Mary, do go down to the village and give her this shilling; I will beg papa, presently, to send our a∣pothecary to her mother,

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh, miss, what a pity you are not always good, how eve∣ry body would love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I hope they will in fu∣ture.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Juliet, what are you going to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I am going to read to Mrs. Selwyn, in her own room, and afterwards Charles and I are going to play.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Very well, then I will finish my letter to mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
Do so.—I shall not stay long with Mrs. Selwyn.—Let
me know, Mary, when my father comes in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes, miss. (Ju∣liet goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Miss Juliet seems very unhappy to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Yes, she has naturally a strong sense of what is right; she feels that she is wrong, and of course is unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I cannot help loving her, though she is sometimes so much out of the way. She was a sweet child before she grew so passionate, and she has a great deal of good about her still. How my poor lady would have grieved had she lived to see her so head-strong.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
Had it pleased Hea∣ven to spare Mrs. Beecher, Juliet would probably have been a very
different character; she has an ad∣mirable understanding, but she is ill educated.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: That's true, indeed, miss. I take the liberty of speak∣ing to you because you know how I love all this family, and that I have lived in it long enough to know something about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Yes, Mary, you may speak to me without fear; I know your attachment to your late lady and all that belonged to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Ah, miss, I wish my young lady lived with you, you are so mild and so sensible, and my lady your mother is so fine a char∣acter—

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I have reason to glo∣ry in my mother—May I be one day like her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P:
You will, miss, nay, you are already; truly I hear of you
from all parts.—But I know yo don't wish to be praised.—What I was going to say, is this:—Nobo∣dy hears us!—No—Indeed, Miss Paulina, Mrs. Selwyn is not fit to have the care of my young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: It is true indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: She sets her no example but laziness, and she teazes her out of her wits;—if you had but heard her this morning—

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
I see it with pain. She has no command over my cou∣sin, because she puts herself on a le∣vel with her by mean teazing and raillery;—a passionate temper was never mended by irritation.—By the way, I don't much like this scheme of playing with Charles; Juliet and he always quarrel, and I am afraid he will overthrow all her good resolutions. I mean to speak to my uncle, to-night, about Mrs.
Selwyn, not to blame or censure her, but merely to say I think she does not exactly follow the right method of managing my cousin's temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Truly I think not.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I intend to ask my un∣cle to let Juliet return with me, I know mama wishes it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I wish he may, miss, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Well, I will go and write my letter.

DIV2.STAGE: (She is going, when Juliet rushes in apparently much terrified.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh Paulina!—Mary—Help, help!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh dear, miss what, is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: My brother!—help—help him—go to him.
SP.STAGE: (Mary runs out, Juliet sinks down with her head against a chair, Paulina goes to her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Cousin!—My dear Juliet, what is the matter?—Oh, Heaven! she is fainting!—What shall I do, shall I run to Charles?—No, I cannot leave this dear girl.—Juliet, revive, smell to my salts.—
SP.STAGE: (Juliet recovering, rises on her knees, and clings round Pauli∣na.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh, Paulina!—Send for some help.—Run to my father.—My father!—Good Heaven! he will hate me for ever.—I shall be banished his sight; plead for me Paulina!—Wretched girl!—What will become of me!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: For pity's sake tell me what you have done?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: What have I done?—I know not!—Perhaps I have kill∣ed my brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: (shudders and shrinks back.) Unhappy girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh! well may you shud∣der, well may you look at me with horror!—You who warned me; how dare I clasp my arms round you.—Those hands, which, (how can I five to tell it) perhaps have murdered my brother. (She faints)

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: With what terror do I hear her, (She leans over her.) Wretched victim of ungovern'd passion!—Revive, fear not my re∣proaches!—Ah, thou art already too miserable!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Ah, miss, what shall we do?—I have sent for a surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: How is he hurt?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Alas! I know not how much, the knife has struck him near the eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: The knife!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P:
Yes, they were at play and quarrelled, Miss Juliet had a
knife in her hand, which she threw at him.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: How dreadful!—let us run to him!—Yet, Juliet! But why should I seek to revive her!—Unhappy creature, she wakes but to woe—Perhaps he may be blind∣ed!—I stiffen with horror!—Ah I hear the surgeon; follow me, Mary!

Paulina, where am I!—You will not speak!—What have I done!—Ah I remember—too, too well I remember!— (She raises her∣self)—They are gone!—They leave me!—to die alone!—Alas I deserve it!—Am I worthy that one creature should pity me!—Yet the torments I endure!—Can they alone for my crimes?—Ne∣ver, never!—Dreadful idea!—must I suffer thro' life the anguish I
feel at this moment?—Thro' life—what terrible fears crowd upon me!— (She kneels,) Oh God of mer∣cy! hear me, pity me!—Ah He is a God of justice!—Can he for∣give me who have murdered my Brother?—What a wretch am I!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Miss Juliet, are you better?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Yes, Mary.—Have you seen—

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Your brother?—yes, Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah, you weep!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Truly yes, I am fright∣ened to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I am the unhappy cause.—I dread to hear—I dare not ask.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: The surgeon is with him; I could not stay any longer to see him suffer so.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Suffer!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes, the surgeon is o∣bliged to hurt him, to find if the wound is—I cannot speak it.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Mortal you would say? How is it that I have courage to pronounce that horrible word?—Ah, I gather courage from the ex∣cess of my despair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh my poor master, what will he say!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Do not distract me!—Pity for a moment the pangs I suffer!—Leave me, Mary, leave me, I implore you!—Go, learn if there is any hope!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
I have lost every∣thing!—My father will drive me from him for ever—I shall quit every thing I love!—My friends, my relations will blush when my name is mentioned—Never more
shall I revisit these scenes, so dear to my infancy!—Let me not re∣call the years I have past—years of innocence and happiness!—Go where I will, I shall be pointed at and hated.—Even the picture of my mother, which used in all my distresses to console me, I can never fee again.—I should fancy it re∣proached me.—And all this mise∣ry I have incurred by one moment of passion!—Oh God, if thou should'st this once deign to save me, never, never, will I be guilty again!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Juliet!—my dear cousin!—be comforted.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah! what then!—What!—may I, dare I hope!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Yes—the surgeon says he is in no danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet
SP.P: (throwing herself into her arms.) Oh my best Paulina!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: (embracing her with tears.) I ran to you the instant I heard it.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I have not deserved your goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Ah Juliet!—if the knife had gone ever so little on one side, Charles would have been kil∣led, or on the other, and he would have been blinded for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh merciful Almighty God!—from what misery has thy providence preserved me!—even now I cannot behold myself with∣out horror.—Have I deserved the mercy I have met with?—No!—tho' innocent in intention, my action was guilty—I could not wish to hurt my brother, yet took the means to do so!—Detested passion!—Oh Paulina, I am cured for ever!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
I dare hope so!—
The lessons of this day have been striking.—They shew how one step in evil leads to another.—Aweful and horrid might have been the e∣vent, but as it has proved, we will hope this instruction has been di∣rected by Providence, to warn you of your danger!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: It has done it com∣pletely.—But Paulina, where is my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I hear him now in the hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh Paulina, I dare not see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I will go to him, and I hope, return with your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: My best friend—let actions speak my gratitude, deign but to counsel and direct me, henceforth I will be guided by you alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Well, Miss Juliet, make yourself easy, all goes well.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Thank God!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: You have had good fortune, Miss, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Good fortune, Ma'am! I dare to consider it as the act of Divine Providence, if not to save me, yet to preserve my father from misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: You improve, Miss, your language is really fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Misfortunes correct the heart, and strong feelings excite strong expression.—I hope I shall improve.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: You astonish me—you who but this morning were dressing your doll, to be making wise remarks, is indeed surprising.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I am not a fool, tho' I have acted like one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P:
No, no, they an't very
wise that take you for a fool. I have often heard you talk to my master as sensible as any-body in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Miss Juliet ne∣ver indulged me with any of her sensible conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Truly no, because you treated her like a baby.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: You take great liberties.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, Ma'am, but I have often told you you did not know my young lady so well as I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: The more sense she has, the more shame for her to behave as she has done.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
Too true indeed!—my conscience tells me I have not the excuse of folly.—But I have suf∣fered passion to over-run and darken many good qualities. This one
hour has driven it from my heart. I am no longer a foolish child.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Come, my dearest Juliet—Charles is with your fa∣ther, he knows all, he forgives you, he calls for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I owe every-thing to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I have more good news for you—one word.
SP.STAGE: (Mrs. Selwyn and Mary retire to the back of the Scene.)
SP.P: You go home with me—you are to stay with us as long as you please!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Delightful!—

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Your father dismisses Mrs. Selwyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah I am sorry! She is poor, and she has taught the ma∣ny things.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
My good cousin, how
I love that gratitude!—your fa∣ther will allow her a pension, we have settled all that since I left you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh my best cousin!—how much do I owe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I am overpaid if you are happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: To be so I must be good.—That will be the work of your hands!—How will you be loved by your friends, by your mother, by Heaven itself!—yes that will repay you.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Let us go, my uncle expects us.
